They also have coffee, tea, bottled water and juice... and other food (I've never read the menu), so it's good for other, non-pastry late night needs. I really wish the coffee was better - or at least kept in sealed coffee dispensers instead of open coffee pots on warming plates. Good coffee would have made this a 5 star review (hint, hint).
author: Kristina A.

description:
Swarms of flies and cheap donuts, what a great combo. 

I'm sure they're probably trying to keep it clean but there's always swarms of flies everywhere (at least during the daytime). Today, I saw a fly buzzing around inside the little display case where all the donuts are displayed and no one even noticed. 

When I use the tiny, dirty bathroom in the back, the raw dough is just laid out all exposed, I could spit on them if I wanted to. The donuts are baked fresh daily and very light and inexpensive. Too bad I'm a little weary about eating their donuts now. 

The cold-cut sandwiches aren't spectacular, but I like turkey and it will have to do for $4. The 1st time the bread was toasted, 2nd time it wasnt, 3rd time only the top bun was toasted? Maybe I should just automatically start telling them that I want it toasted from now. 

The croissant sandwiches are greasy as hell. Skip it. 

The workers are really nice. 

I got a sandwich, chips, donut, and a drink for $8.00. Score for being open 24-hours and inexpensively cheap! Minus the stars for the dirty health conditions in the back that we don't know about.
author: Joraine C.

description: It's all terrible for you but when its late and you want food, it's a godsend. Remember to ask them to heat up the donuts so it's softer and just a bit more delicious.
author: Rohan D.

description:
"I feel like hot chocolate this morning." I thought as I got off the J-bus. I didn't know the same of this place when I walked in. But I ask for a hot chocolate, and then I see a platter of doughnuts! 

OH YES! DONUTS! =D I try to look away, not give into temptation. I see the croissant sandwiches and get a sausage one. Both came out pretty cheap, and the croissant sandwich was much bigger than I expected. 

The ONLY reason why this is a 4 star ---------CASH ONLY =(
author: Sophia G.

description: I hate to give a good donut 2 stars, but this lady was soooo rude. She acted to annoyed to have to help me and peeved that I wanted to have fresh juice from her fresh juice machine. (she said no) You can tell it's her shop and she should only have donuts on the menu...she can't handle preparing other foods while serving other customers and took her stress out on me and my husband. We felt so sad she'd been so harsh that we barely enjoyed the yummy donut.
author: Katrina H.

description:
Considering how much I love donuts - it is not a wonder that I am not 500 lbs by now.  Happy Donuts is good for donuts - but AMAZING for LATE NIGHT donuts.  After the bars close, Happy Donuts has a team of donut maker extrordinaires on hand - think Ompa Loompas. FRESH, Warm donuts after a night of binge drinking and playing erotic photo hunt (with RICHARD G. and DesNeiges G.) - there is nothing better.  Ok so they may be a bit slow making the donuts at 2 am, but hell I am drunk and my thinking is a bit impaired so who cares how long I have to wait...as long as I get that tasty tasty donut to end my night.

Are you Happy now Richard !? ;)
author: Jenn C.

description:
A: "So, what are we doing tonight?"

B: "Dunno, let's just meet at happy donuts"

A: "What time?"

B: "Meh, the usual"

and then around 9PM between 4 and 7 teenagers all wander in from different directions in the city. Two of us trekking up the hill on the 48, One migrating from forest hill, one one lucky enough to only hop the J. 

Maybe it was the central location that attracted us, or the close proximity to liquor stores that didn't check ID's or perhaps it was the delicious donuts and our ambivalence to planning ahead of time. But regardless of the reasons, this was out meet up spot on a Friday night before we'd embark on a great adventure involving our underage inebriation.

Good things about this place are that you can sit inside waiting for people without buying anything, although if you want to use the bathroom, you'll have to buy something. The donuts are really really good, always. The staff looks the other way when you are mixing drinks at your table and pouring them into water bottles.
author: Allyson S.

description: Not sure what's so "happy" about these things, but the plain buttermilk bar tasted, well, plain. Nicely located across from the inbound J Muni stop.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
I love this place, they're prices are awesome especially for breakfast sandwiches or croissants  but it does have a couple of irritating things you should know.

1. they're always out of chocolate milk...they can't get it right.

2. they refused to give me ketchup one day because i wasn't buying anything, even though i had purchased a bagel earlier that same day.

other than that you receive service with a smile everyday and the owners work very hard to please everyone.
author: adam f.

description: Right at the 24th Street J-line stop at church sits this little gem.  The pastries are tasty and its open 24 hrs.  Best of all, you can jump in and grab a donut to eat while you wait for the J line to take you into the city!
author: David S.

description: This donut shop is anything but "happy".  C'mon, why do we only have this donut shop in the area?  I've stopped by this donut shop on my way to work three times now and have regretted it every time.  The donuts here taste awful, old and stale.  The lady at the cash register doesn't seem to speak english and her husband who speaks a little is unfriendly and kind of rude.  I want to suport small local businesses but just can't support this one anymore.  I wish another donut shop would open nearby to offer this community some freshly made, delicious and warm donuts.
author: Claire D.

description:
I live a very short block away from this place. But that's not quite close enough. One of my dreams is to live in an apartment directly above Happy Donuts. Picture this... walk downstairs at 2am (just after they're finished with a new batch), order 2 glazed twists from that super friendly Chinese kid, chomp on one of those doughy twists before you're up the stairs and work on the second one in the comfort of your apartment. Yes! (pump fist Tiger Woods style on the 18th hole at Torrey Pines). But alas, I don't live above the Happy Donuts.

A sign this place is the real deal is when the parade of cop cars make their ritual stop and take over the place at midnight-ish. C'mon, the Po Po eating your donuts... isn't that the equivalent of at least one Michelin star for donut shops?

Another plus is its proximity to the J Church stop. The bus ride is shorter when you can enjoy donut holes the entire ride.
author: Kevin W.

description: I have memories of coming here when I was 4 and getting donut holes. The freshest donuts are early in the AM and late in the PM.  It is the only place in Noe Valley I can think of that is open 24 hours, not that you'd probably be up being crazy that late in Noe Valley.  The place often has cops and firefighters hanging around, which is enjoyable and very Simpsons.  I came here after my high school prom too.  It is a landmark and a force to be reckoned with.
author: Julia D.

description:
I love donuts.  I try not to eat donuts.  Happy Donuts is a good place to break my donut rule.

Donuts are fresh.  The coffee looks grim.  I drink milk with my donuts.  And, yes, they have that too.  The apple fritter looks large enough to feed a family.  I'm partial to cake donuts.  I really dig the boringly plain unadorned one.  Tasty!

Last time I was in there in was past midnight.  The place was empty except for me, my dining partners and a father and his young son. I guess it's better than hanging at the local pub with him.
author: Liz P.

description: I live right across the street and have visited this place more times than I'd like to admit. As the only place on 24th Street that's open 24 hours, it does attract an interesting crowd at 2 a.m. on a weeknight.  Usually it's a combination of a couple of police officers, a couple of students with their textbooks, some late night characters just hanging out doing nothing, maybe a few folks that are still drunk from finishing up their last drinks at the Dubliner across the way that just closed.  Good doughnuts, and especially good after 2 a.m.
author: Brian C.

description:
I eschewed this place for ages because 1) it's donuts, and donuts are bad for you (my healthy-earthy-crunchy doctor's office is in Noe Valley and I'm terrified she'll catch me in there), and 2) it looks cheap or cheesy or like the donuts would be shipped from across the city or something. I guess I'm too much yuppie.

But then one day I overcame my fear and bought a donut. Ooooh, yes ma'am. They are WONDERFUL. Fresh-tasting, soft, lovely -- really, really, really good. I asked, and they make those donuts RIGHT THERE. The glazed cinnamon swirl things are OH YES. They know how to glaze a donut. It's all fresh and crackly and not a bit soggy. 

This is my secret decadent pleasure from time to time. At least, it was a secret until now. Dr. ______, forgive me.
author: Brooke H.

description: Donuts, sure. They're cheap and they taste fine. I don't understand why Yelp requires the review box to be filled, especially for places like this.
author: Grant M.

description:
These donuts are just OK.  I wouldn't really recommend them unless you find yourself nearby.  Not worth a bus ride.

Tried a chocolate buttermilk and a glazed.  Glazed not so hot, buttermilk OK.  Neither set the house on fire and I had a fire extinguisher ready.

These donuts were not the cheapest - $1.95 for both.  (Jelly Donut in the Mission was 2 (or really 3) for $1.50).

Eh.
author: Aaron T.

description:
Riding by this place on the J-Church is sheer torture. 

The donuts waft through the open door at the 24th Street stop, pulling you out of the train as if you were in a sugar and fried bread-laced hallucination. Screw it, you say, you'll take the next train. 

The shop isn't fancy, isn't posh, isn't trendy. After all, it's donuts, so you don't except Naomi to walk in and throw her phone at anyone. But that's a good thing. You get a chocolate old fashioned and a rainbow sprinkle, and wash them down with some seriously concentrated orange juice. 

You don't know what time of day it is, and you don't care. You're in donut nirvana. Yum.
author: Aaron L.

description: Pretty good donuts. We had a maple cruller which was crisp on the outside and airy in the inside. Great spot for a snack..except the coffee...skip the coffee
author: Lisa H.

description:
I am a fan of reviewing Happy Donuts. A well know name, but each and every Happy Donut cafe seem to have their own uniqueness and charm. First of all this is by far one of my favorites. 1. Because it's down a the street from the Dubliner, and a late night donut after a night of drinking is YUM YUM YUMS.  2. It's right across the GYM. hahaha. 3. This Happy Donut is welcoming enough to enjoy during the day. 

This Happy Donuts had a nice big windows allowing ample amounts of sunlight to spill into the place. Nice hardwood floors vs. cold tiles at many other Happy's. It's right on on a bustling corner, which is a good place to sit, sip on coffee, eat my old fashion chocolate gazed donut. GO check it out. Sure the donuts is nothing extremely unique, but compared to many other donut places, there nothing dingy about this one. It's a quite the pleasant place.
author: MJ T.

description: Mmm. 24 hour donuts. I love coming here late at night after hitting up the bars. Forget Krispy Kreme, this is my favorite donut shop.
author: Zell C.

description:
When I was very depressed, I used to walk to this place, buy an apple fritter and then go back home eating. 

After a few months, I got better. I don't think my getting better and the donuts are related but never put all your bags in the same egg.

The fritters are good, the staff is friendly and it's very cheap.
author: Bobby T.

description: Great donuts.  I judge a donut by the chocolate glazed donut and this place makes a great fluffy donuts.   Light, slightly sweet and just delicious. I would have to say, their donuts are not as sweet as other shops.  If you're used to an overbearingly sweet donut like krispy kreme, look else where.   I also tried some of their more specialty donuts.  which was also delicious.
author: Sam C.

description: This review is on service alone because I do like their donuts... But, don't go there after hours especially on Friday and Saturday when you would think a donut shop would have donuts to sell to the stumbling drunks.  Because for some reason they stay open and only have about 5 donuts that look like they were made that afternoon.  And not to mention the guy that works nights is a dick, give him the bird and say its from Filthy.
author: Alex K.

description:
Best  2 things about Happy Donuts. 
1. The maple bars.
2. They are  open 24 hours. 
I  can't  tell you how happy a maple bar has made me  and  my friends at 2am after a nite  out! The  donuts aren't bad any other time of the  day as well!
author: Tara T.

description: I always wanted to find an excuse to go there because it is open all night but they didn't have anything to eat that sounded good to me.  Old weird place on the corner.  Strange Asian employees, pretty friendly once you spent money.  Lame coffee.  I would just go there now and then because I felt sorry for them.
author: Cynthia B.

description: Even with all the by-the-book tricks to combat jet lag (sleeping pills, moderate amounts of alcohol, flying east to west), invariably after 26 hours of traveling, I found myself asleep at 6pm and wide awake around 2am. In a city that's lacking with late night dining options, Happy Donuts is a subtle but spectacular icon. Back home, I settled in with a Happy Donuts' apple fritter in one hand, sipping my Black Bush neat and watching Coco Before Chanel into the morning hours. Sort of an unexpected combination but surprisingly quite inspirational. Armed with a nice sugar rush and thoughts of Chanel beauty, next stop is Etsy to uncover whimsical elegant treasures.
author: Jane K.

description:
ALWAYS ALWAYS friendly
Great & fresh donuts, OPEN 24 HOURS!
Try the melted ham & cheese...
author: Michael K.

description: Second best donuts in San Francisco, nearly perfect.  Light, not greasy - hands will never have any oil after consumption.  Also, sodas are just $0.80 -- 20% cheaper than the 'convenience' store next door!  Brewed coffee is magnificent, French Roast is dark and lovely.
author: mimi n.

description:
I love me some Happy Donuts! Especially after a late night out. But, really, any time of the day is a good time for donuts. 

Raspberry filled donuts are my fave. The donut holes are very satisfying, as well. 

Leave your plastic at home -  only cold hard cash accepted here.
author: Ms P.

description: I was craving for donuts, and found this place on yelp.  Im so glad i did, we discover a block of lil shops and stuff.. the donuts were HUGE, and BOMB!!  I wish they had more to choose from... the girl was cute and friendly, she seemed a bit shy tho LOL
author: La La T.

description: Dependable old-fashion doughnut shop. You will be surprised how good the coffee is, if you get it fresh. Friendly staff too.
author: Leonard G.

description: Hey, still 5 stars, nothing has changed, but I did get a jelly donut without any jelly in it.  No big deal, I'm sure injecting donuts with tasty raspberry filling gets monotonous and you can skip over one every now and then.  I win a prize or something, it's like finding a golden ticket, right?
author: Andy B.

description:
I love the donuts.  It's a shame the woman who works here is rude.
5 stars for donuts
No stars for service--
I figured 3 stars because they are damned good donuts.
author: Jaymi Marie P.

description: This place is absolute heaven when walking home from the Mission at night. It's open 24/7 so that I can stuff my face with great donuts at any time of the day. How awesome is that?
author: X O.

description: Wow! Wow! This place is amazing. If you like donuts, you need to get some at Happy Donuts. The donuts are always fresh (we stopped in last night at 12am and they were totally fresh) and the place is open 24/7 -- amazing!!
author: Lee D.

description:
Stumbling home from "out"
What's better than a doughnut?
Thank you, Happy Ds.
author: Alana D.

description:
as josua p. pointed out in a recent review of another donut place, donuts with pink frosting are just about the greatest thing ever.  every donut should be coated with pink frosting and multi-colored sprinkles.  and be served to you on a cloud by an angel.  

it is seriously my one regret in veganism that i will never get to try a pink frosted donut from happy donuts.

however, they serve a french vanilla coffee here that satisfies my sweet tooth when i add my own silk brand vanilla soy creamer (tm) (THIS STUFF IS SO GOOD IF YOU HAVE NEVER TRIED IT IN YOUR COFFEE YOU ARE MISSING OUT EVEN DAIRY DRINKERS SAY IT IS BETTER THAN 1/2 AND 1/2 GO TO WHOLE FOODS OR RAINBOW OR WHEREVER AND GET SOME RIGHT NOW!)  

-1 star for no vegan donut.  but that's about all the negative i can say about this place.  even the people that work there are cute about not having a vegan donut and when i ask (as i always do...i feel like if i'm persistent enough, i'll get somewhere.  i approach  most of life this way which is probably why i am pretty consistently disappointed) they smile and laugh and say, "HAHAHA not today!" and then i laugh too and it is cute.  but really inside, i am sad.  and i'm sure they're annoyed that this stupid bitch asks for vegan donuts at least twice a week.

****EMERGENCY SUPER IMPORTANT EDIT:  they have a vegan donut!  they have many, in fact!  it is of the cake variety and you can get it with cinnamony sugar crumbles or powdered sugar or delicious cakey cake and it is GOOD!!!  i am giving 5 stars even through they still don't have a g-d vegan pink frosted donut for me.  when they get one of those, they will be upgraded to 6 stars.  trust me, i will make the 6th star happen if i have to kill tom l. for it!)****
author: Laura B.

description: Damn you, Eric, for living around the corner from this den of caloric iniquity, and shame on me for not having enough will power to ignore the lure of their chocolate-covered custard-filled donut every time I visit you.
author: Gourmet G.

description:
The wee hours of the morning bring forth a screeching halt to the city's nightlife  as seekers of frolic spill out onto the street, then trickle back to the towns and neighborhoods from whence then came.  Soon thereafter, San Francisco's  level of energy drops from mildly-boisterous to barely-tepid as a uniform blanket of eerie silence slowly envelops it's sidewalks.  Still, it's streets elicit an ever-so-faint heartbeat... one that's formed by a scant few souls that remain out-and-about after the stroke of two, and fueled by a dwindling collection of businesses who cater to them....

Happy Donut is barely visible during the hustle and bustle of Noe Valley's daytime scene, but it's neon lighting and unlocked door stick out in oasis-like fashion come the stroke of midnight.  Walking amidst the tomb-like silence of 24th Street during the wee hours of the morn, it's brightly lit windows and visibly inviting pastry counter forms a lighthouse-like beacon that calls out to insomniacs, tweakers, and burners-of-midnight-oil.

Big windows facing both 24th and Church Streets give Happy Donuts a nice view as night yields to dawn, and dawn gives way to daybreak. No matter when you arrive, there's always at least one other night-urchin camped out at a table.  The staff....even the graveyard shift, are kindly and polite, and seem to view late-night customers as a welcome break from the drudgery of cooking donuts.  The layout is definitely geared more towards eat-and-run rather than sip-and-linger, but linger I have....and the staff never seems to mind in the slightest.  The pastry selection is on par with the average donut shop, though a cheesecake-like item they prepare in sheets and serve in squares is nothing short of stellar.  I always get a turkey sandwich on a French roll.  It's quality is on par with that of the average daytime deli, but relatively exceptional when compared to anything else that's available between two and six AM.
  
Happy Donuts represents an island of simple pleasures in a surrounding bog of gentrification run amok.  It's an oasis of affordable indulgences mired amongst a nauseating array of chic boutiques and spendy bistros.  And come two in the morn, it's glowing windows elicit a subtle welcome from within the dark mass or Noe Valley's shuttered storefronts:

Give me your wired, your hungry,
Your restless souls yearning for something to eat.
The wretched refuse of night-life play.
Send these, the sleepless, lonely souls to me.
My neon glow beckons 24 hours a day!
author: Mike W.

description:
It is so difficult to find good donuts in the city; Happy Donut is probably the best I have found.  The donut holes are usually well frosted and fresh, the chocolate cinnamon twists are divine, and the regular varieties of glazed and cake donuts provide a lighter breakfast when the twist is too daunting.
I have never tried the coffee or other drinks, but these appear to be popular with other regulars.  Very friendly staff, too.
author: John C.

description: Go here at 2am and ask of whomever is working what's available fresh at the moment.  That's the only thing you need to know.  Seriously, put this on your calendar as something to do.
author: Oliver N.

description:
I used to stop by Happy Donuts on occasion before I would head on over to my Italian class a few blocks away.  
I'd sit there, have a drink, and you know, a little something to eat while practicing my verbs n' shit because my darn procrastinating self decided to neglect my duties until the next day (this always backfires on me, but for some reason I continue doing it.)
The hot pastrami sandwich is pretty good, especially when I was feelin' ravenous from flying light all day.  
I'm not much of a donut-eater, though, I do enjoy a fabulously tasty one every so often.  
And these are the ones.  
So fluffy, so light, so chocolicious. 
I stick with the regular ol' chocolate dipped one. 
But all of them look tasty, and although I do possess the mighty skill to devour each and every one of them, I dare not do it because you know that once you go sprinkle, sugar, and frosting there's no going back!

The shop is just about no frills at all and I don't mind, as long as I have a nice big window and a good place to sit I'm fine.  

Allllsssooo, I'm not sure if it's part of a 'Happy Donuts' chain, it seems like an independent shop to me, but even if it was I would still like it.  It's a comfortably clean place and the lady who I usually ordered from was always *really* nice, which to me is reason enough for 5 STARS.

BAM!

Oh, and here's a little vid to get you donut lovers in the mood.
http://youtube.com/watch?v=wEZHGe2S9vc
author: Natalie D.

description:
A great 24 hour joint if you live near Noe Valley... it is the perfect morning, afternoon, or late night snack.  Sure, it's no Dunkin Donuts, but they don't have those out here, so Happy Donuts is my go-to donut place.

The folks are super friendly too.
author: Jon S.

description: There are people who say you can't buy happiness, but they have obviously never been to Happy Donut.
author: A. D.

description: A clean, comfortable, friendly shop with the yummifers known as donuts. Did I just say yummifers?
author: Allison L.

description: their old fashioned definately left me feeling happy with my donuts this morning
author: Kayhan V.

description: Someone told me that all the HD's are independently owned. Not sure if that is true but every one I've been in has the same great tasting 'nuts. I first discovered Happy Donut when I worked around the corner from the one at Battery and Market. They had great sandwiches - one with pork and cilantro that blew my mind - follow it up with a maple bar and wow - that's good shit. I eat fruit shakes for lunch every day now and my life is like a dark cloud over a stinky cesspool.
author: Colin S.

description:
i went to happy donuts.  i was sad.  i was tired.  i wanted donuts.

i opted for a dozen donuts, because it would make me happy to share donuts, and because the variable pricing of donuts confused me.

as i was three-fourths of the way through ordering my variety of donuts, the woman serving me began to tell me that most of my donuts would cost more than normal, and i couldn't get them in a dozen donuts.

now, is a dozen donuts a dozen cake or frosted donuts?  no.  a dozen donuts is a dozen donuts.  i would be happy paying seven dollars for a dozen cake or frosted donuts, but unless that's specified on the menu, i would like a dozen of ANY KIND of donuts in my dozen donuts.

i didn't get any donuts on that trip.  which was sad, because i was sad, and because the donuts looked delicious.
author: Puck F.

description: I consider myself something of an apple fritter connoisseur, as I consider the fritter to be one of the greatest foods available to man.  The apple fritters at Happy Donuts are the size of dinner plates; I'm sure they weigh in at over 12 pounds at purchase.  Fear not, though - there is no sacrifice of quality for quantity: they are fantastic.
author: J R.

description: Donuts at all hours of the day....dangerously cool. Avoid if drunk.
author: James J.

description: In my opinion a donut shop can be judged by it's 1) old fashioned donuts and 2) coffee. Didn't have the coffee (honestly I skipped it because it looked weak and utterly avoidable) but the old fashioned donuts held up to my standards sufficiently. And this place is open 24 hours which means I can have donuts at 3 in the morning. Any time is a good time for a donut really. Next time I'm having one of the apple fritters. They look enormously delicious.
author: Kristin S.

description: Sandwiches and donuts. Service is polite and snappy. Sandwiches are tasty, but nothing special, just your standard cold-cut sandwiches. I bought 3 lunches for my friendly Corrib movers (sandwich, chips, banana) for under $16. Then I came back to get lunch for me, my mom, and the lady, also for under $16.
author: Rob T.

description: Happy Donuts in Noe Valley is great! The donuts are always fresh and it's one of the cleanest donut shops in the city.
author: Danielle D.

description: Dunno what it is abt these donuts.  But these are among the best I've ever had!  Every time I've gone, the donuts are super fresh.  The old fashioned cake ones are heavenly.
author: Natasha S.

description:
best plain old fashioned donuts! 

a friend lives a few blocks away, so a couple of times on our way home, we stopped by to get a donut or two. we tried their hot sandwiches as well, and they were yummy! esp at 3 am. anyway, on to the old fashioned donuts, my favorite kind. the ones they served here were super crispy on the outside, but moist and soft on the inside. it was just perfect. 79 cents.

the service was always friendly, the guy always smiling. good stuff.
author: Aiko L.

description: Fresh made donuts at 3 in the morning. They make a mean sandwich too. At least it sure is good when it's late and you're drunk.
author: David P.

description: Stopped by for a evening sweet snack. Donuts were very fresh at 9pm, and the restaurant was clean. The service was friendly. What more could you want?
author: Becca R.

description: This is one of the few places that is truly open 24 hrs. So many times after a night on the town did i find myself saying, "man i want a donut!". And best of all, they're delicious! The only peeve i have about it is that they're not very friendly about letting you use their bathroom. Overall, love you happy d!
author: Casey Z.

description: I've been IN LOVE with the cake donut with the chocolate frosting for several years now however, they are USUALLY out by the time I get there afternoon !  So I get an Apple Fritter instead and they are pretty darn good.
author: Jooles M.

description: by far the best donuts in the whole city. the hot chocolate is bomb too!!!
author: maria a.

description: Delicious donuts.  Friendly people behind the counter who remember what you like to order.  Unbelievably genius to start frying new donuts right around last call a the Dubliner.
author: George O.

description: not dunkin donuts :(  not even close.  well at least they have non-dairy donuts for those of you hanging with 'those kinds' of friends.  we ordered 2 donuts.  the lady asked, for here or to go?  it's kind of silly getting donuts 'for here' but we did and ate them out of a paper lined basket.
author: Monk R.

description: 2.5 stars. i'm just rounding up cuz i like your donuts. the donuts are pretty cheap & good.. its just the ladys a total bitch behind the counter! she mugs me & my friends every chance she gets. and she doesn't like our questions. BOO.
author: Coco C.

description:
check out my post about their apple fritters on my blog...

http://sweetladysass.blogspot.com/2009/06/frikin-fritters.html
author: alex K.

description:
when I'm on the J on the way to work, and life seems horrid, I get off at 24th and go to Happy Donuts and get the #5 and it makes life perfect like magic. 

* love love love *
author: Shelley S.

description: So nice to have a 24 hour a day place near where you live. You can get a decent roast beef on a roll or one of their melted ham and cheese croissants in pretty short order anytime of the day. I'm happy with everything that I've had so don't let the appearance fool you, the place serves decent food at a very reasonable price 24/7.
author: Michael G.

description: i came heer after school wit my brother and his friend and we were each going to put in 2 dollars for a dozen.i ordered 2 long jons and she said it wouldbe a little more.i thought it would be like 50 cents butno it was 3 dollars i could of gotten a dozen donuts and 2 long jons for that.to top it off the donuts wer heavy
author: avery N.
